awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research: Developing REsilient African cities and their urban environMent facing the pro-vision of essential urban SDGs (DREAMS)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 55-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum.  The Belmont Forum is a consortium of research funding organizations focused on support for transdisciplinary approaches to global environmental change challenges and opportunities.  The forum aims to accelerate delivery of the international research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders. This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions. This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries.  The teams will establish transdisciplinary networks to develop innovative solutions for sustainable development pathways and seek to assess the positive and negative inter-linkages between the economy, technology, institutions with the environment, climate, biodiversity, and human well-being to understand potential pathways to a sustainable world.

The project focuses on developing and accessing scenarios for sustainable urban development planning in three African cities.  The project combines, natural and social science methodologies with smart computer-based solutions to provide city planners with visual and quantitative information on the state of the environment and potential impacts under different scenarios.   The project team seeks to intensify the cooperation between planners focusing particularly on urban fringes.  Typically, these areas are the most critical parts in cities, where formal instruments to coordinate informal settlements are lacking, often resulting in highly negative trade-offs in risk management (flood, fire), health and sanitation, and air quality.  The results of this research project will help us understand how communities can create more sustainable development pathways.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
DREAMS project was implemented by an international consortium including the United States.

Urban developments in major African cities are often out of governmental control especially in informal settlements of major cities where growth is largely driven by informal social networks.  The DREAMS project is aimed at developing an approach for participatory scenario modelling, impact assessment and integrated strategic planning. In particular, to develop an integrated approach for participatory scenario development that anticipates the future development of informal settlements in African cities with regard to key driving forces, namely climate and global change, and their social, economic, and ecological impacts.  The unique approach used in the DREAMS project lies in combining a social science based participatory approach (Charette system) with geospatial analyses. This allowed for scenario assessment in structured process that facilitated the involvement of local stakeholders and experts to examine relevant information for collaborative decision making about informal settlements regarding different development and upgrading scenarios.  It helped to build a sustainable partnership for achieving the SDGs in the development of African cities within the framework of SDG #17.  
Knowledge Transfer: One outcome of the DREAMS project is knowledge transfer through integrating insights three African cities, where one (Cape Town, South Africa) provided initial context and examples for upgrading slums that were used as foundation for Charette activities and collaborative planning in the other Cities, namely Acca, Ghana and Kampala, Uganda. Additionally, by integrating the DREAMS workshops field activities in Kampala Uganda, we provided professional development opportunity for participants at two Landscape Ecology Summer Schools (https://vwsummerschool.mak.ac.ug/series/summer-school-2022-cities-and-urban-ecological-resilience) that were focused on Cities and Urban ecological resilience in Africa.  This offered experiential learning opportunities for PhD students and early career scholars through site visits for summer school participants who were selected from about 30 African countries.

 Role of Open Geospatial Data: The Charrette process employed in the DREAMS project consisted of intensive and time-constrained public participatory activities that were premised on preparatory phase which included problem definition, the identification of stakeholders, and the identification of information and physical logistics. One key insight from the Cherrette process was the impact of poor data and/or obsolete data on the Charrette design and planning outcomes. Specifically, the lack of relevant information logistics, including updated land use change and environmental data raised the need for easy access to publicly and freely available open and big data on urban landscape dynamics support planning for urban growth and resilience in especially informal settlements. This led some members of the DREAMS international consortium to author a perspective paper that addresses the need for easily accessible open data and big data, including remotely sensed earth observation data, to facilitate assessment of urban pattern development and participatory scenario development:

Banzhaf, E., Bulley, H. N., Inkoom, J. N., & Elze, S. (2022). Mapping Open Data and Big Data to Address Climate Resilience of Urban Informal Settlements in Sub-Saharan Africa. Climate, 10(12), 186.

Information Sharing: Another core outcome of the DREAMS project activities is a conference symposium on Informal Settlements and Urban Landscape Change in the Global South  at the IALE 2023 World Congress in Nairobi, Kenya in July 2023

Session Description: Population growth in the Global South already outpace the developed countries, with African emerging as one of the fastest urbanizing regions of the world. Given that more than 68 percent of the world’s population projected to live in urban areas by 2050, it is of vital importance to understand how the increasing number and precarious locations of informal settlements (slums) within cities and peri-urban areas. A complex combination of rural-urban population pressure, coupled with problematic urban planning frameworks often culminate in diffused urbanization. This this is manifested in incongruent built urbanization process through both extensification (lateral expansion of urban areas into many rural lands) and densification (uncoordinated self-organizing settlements in the urban core) thereby creating to haphazard urban development. Climate change projections of intense rainfall and major floods, as well as recurrent drought have major implications on the people who live in informal settlements, most of which are often located in environmentally sensitive areas. This symposium is an outgrowth of a Belmont Forum transdisciplinary project, DREAMS (Developing REsilient African cities and their urban environMent facing the pro-vision of essential urban SDGs). In particular, brought together presentations from Africa, Latin America and Asia that addressed how informal settlements affect landscape change dynamics in urban areas in the Global South, as well as the influences of climate change on these interactions within the context of achieving Sustainable Development Goals in the developing countries of the Global South.


Environmental Health in Informal Settlements:

Fieldwork in Ashaiman community of Accra, Ghana have yielded a manuscript by the some of the DREAMS collaborators:

Tutu R., D. Ottie-Boakye, and H.N. Bulley.  Rethinking and mapping environmental health literacy and contaminants in Old Tulaku, Greater Accra Region of Ghana. GeoJournal.
